title: Program
text:
Time
Activity




Program COAIM, dates TBA, 2025



Day 1. Organization, function, and dysfunction of the memory system in connection with AD




Moderated by Heikki Tanila


12:30-13:50
Registration and lunch


13:55-14:00
Welcoming address by organizers


14:00-14:30
Anatomical units of space, time and memory. Talk by Prof. Menno Witter, JCA/KISN


14:30-14:40
Questions and discussion


14:40-15:10
Functional units of space, time and memory. Talk by Prof. Edvard/May-Britt Moser, JCA/KISN


15:10-15:20
Questions and discussion


15:20-15:50
Imaging the anatomical and structural units of memory. Talk by Prof. Christian Döller, JCA/KISN and Max Planck Institute for Human Cognitive and Brain Sciences in Leipzig


15:50-16:00
Questions and discussion


16:00-16:20
Break with refreshments


16:20-16:50
Neuron-selective vulnerability in prodromal AD. Talk by Dr. Asgeir Kobro-Flatmoen, The National Union Dementia Centre, KISN, NTNU


16:50-17:00
Questions and discussion


17:00-18:30
Poster session 1


18:30-19:00
The clinical presentation and diagnosis of AD. Talk by Dr. Gøril Rolfseng Grøntvedt, The National Union Dementia Centre, KISN, NTNU


19:00-19:10
Questions and discussion


19:10-19:40
Neurocognitive alterations of entorhinal functioning in preclinical AD. Talk by Prof. Nikolai Axmacher, Ruhr University, Bochum, Germany


19:40-19:50
Questions and discussion


20:15-22:00
Dinner


Day 2, part 1. Central aspects of AD: proteinopathy




Moderated by Asgeir Kobro-Flatmoen


09:00-09:40
Key note lecture – day 2. The filaments of tau and their impact on AD, by Prof. Michel Goedert, University of Cambridge


09:40-09:50
Questions and discussion


09:50-10:20
Sequence of protein changes in AD. Talk By Dietmar Thal, KU-Leuven


10:20-10:30
Questions and discussion


10:30-11:00
Tau and microglia and MTL. Talk by Prof Maria Grazia Spillantini, University of Cambridge


11:00-11:10
Questions and discussion Replacement needed


11:10-11:30
Break with refreshments


11:30-12:00
Early/initiating pathological interactions, Aβ, p-tau and ApoE. Talk by Prof. Gunnar Gouras, Experimental Dementia Research, Lund University


12:00-12:10
Questions and discussion


12:10-12:40
Endosomal dysfunction triggers intraneuronal beta-amyloid in late-onset AD. Talk by Prof. Claudia Almeida, NOVA Medical School, Lisbon, Portugal


12:40-12:50
Questions and discussion


12:50-14:00
Lunch


Day 2, part 2. Central aspects of AD: Early cellular changes, behavior and cognition




Moderated by Tora Bonnevie


14:00-14:30
Roles of inflammation in Alzheimer’s disease and dementia. Talk by Prof. Paul Edison, Imperial College London, UK


14:30-14:40
Questions and discussion


14:40-15:10
Lifestyle and Dementia Risk: Does It Apply to Alzheimer’s? Talk by Prof. Geir Selbæk, Norwegian National Advisory Unit on Ageing and Health, Norway


15:10-15:20
Questions and discussion


15:20-16:30
Poster session 2


16:30-17:00
The viscious circle between neuronal hyperexcitability and AD. Talk by Prof. Heikki Tanila, Uni Eastern Finland


17:00-17:10
Questions and discussion


17:10-17:40
Modeling the onset of p-tau in rats. Talk by Prof. Cliff Kentros, KISN, NTNU


17:40-17:50
Questions and discussion


17:50-18:10
Break with refreshments


18:10-18:40
Microglial changes in early stages of AD. Talk by Prof. Kristine Freude, Department of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, UCPH, Denmark


18:40-18:50
Questions and discussion


18:50-19:20
Ethologically relevant phenotyping of cognitive impairments in AD model mice. Talk by Prof. Julija Krupic, University of Cambridge, UK


19:20-19:30
Questions and discussion


19:30-20:00
Fine-tuning the NAD+-mitophagy axis in healthy brain ageing. Talk by Prof. Evandro Fang


20:00-20:10
Questions and discussion


20:30-22:30
Dinner


Day 3. Translational research on AD




Moderator: Prof. Gunnar Gouras


09:00-09:40
Key note lecture - day 2. Translational research on the AD cascade, by Karen Duff, UK DRI Centre Director, University College London


09:40-09:50
Questions and discussion


09:50-10:20
Alzheimer’s disease biomarkers reflecting neuronal and innate immune brain pathologies and pathomechanisms. Talk by Tormod Fladby


10:20-10:40
Questions and discussion


10:40-11:00
Break with refreshments


11:00-11:30
The Trønderbrain project – Next-generation translational medicine. Talk by Prof. Katja Scheffler, Laboratory leader at Department of Neurology, St. Olavs Hospital, Trondheim


11:30-11:40
Questions and discussion


11:40-12:10
The AD time project, Tora Bonnevie


12:10-12:20
Questions and discussion


12:20-12:30
Closing remarks


12:30-12:45
Organize for departure


12:45-14:00
Lunch


14:00
Departure
